data.title: Warby Parker: Not Worth Its Premium As Growth Slows (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
The stock market in 2026 has been a painful one to invest in, but when we take a step back, it should be a value investor’s dream. A plethora of high-quality enterprise software businesses are now suddenly trading at fire-sale prices, reacting sharply to fears about AI’s competitive threats.

In my view, in a few months we may look back on this period in the stock market as a short-lived crash similar to the early fallout from President Trump’s reciprocal tariffs in April 2025. In the meantime, investors should position our portfolios with careful stock-picking in mind, as many high-quality value plays are deeply oversold and overdue a rebound.

Warby Parker (WRBY), in particular, is a stock that I find to be losing a lot of appeal. The eyeglasses maker, which made waves for its DTC business model and low-cost frames, is up ~15% since the start of January as the market looks forward to the company’s coming AI glasses with Google (GOOG). That said, net new customer growth is slowing down, calling into question the stock’s rich valuation multiples.

I last wrote a neutral article on Warby Parker in December, when the stock was trading at $27 per share. Even though the stock is down ~10% since then, I’m not convinced enough that there’s a compelling enough growth story here to justify a market-topping adjusted EBITDA multiple, especially when gross margins are sliding downward. Amid the emergence of many better small- and mid-cap value plays in the tech sector, Warby Parker’s luster is vastly diminished, and I’m dropping my rating on the stock to sell.

Don’t get me wrong: I don’t necessarily think Warby Parker is a bad business, but I do think it’s mispriced in today’s market. Since valuation is my primary gripe against this stock, let’s open the discussion with a look at the company’s latest guidance and how current valuation multiples stack up against it.

At current share prices near $25, Warby Parker trades at a market cap of $3.06 billion. Netting off the $286.4 million of cash (against zero debt) on the company’s latest balance sheet gives us an enterprise value of $2.77 billion.

As shown in the chart above, for FY26 the company is guiding to 10-12% y/y revenue growth and $117-$119 million in adjusted EBITDA (+23% y/y) that reflects a 12.2% midpoint margin, up slightly from 10.9% in FY25.

This positions Warby Parker's valuation at a sharp 23.5x EV/FY26 multiple. I don't see the appeal in paying a market-topping EBITDA multiple when top line growth is slowing to the low double digits, with customer growth slowing to the single digits.

We note there is "upside risk" from two factors: success in AI glasses and a potential removal of tariffs, which is a major wild card still up in the air. We should remind ourselves, however, that Warby Parker's tech partner here is Google, which failed to get Google Glass off the ground in 2013. Meanwhile, many competitors are rushing in, including Meta (META) (whose partnership with Ray Ban arguably leverages a better-known consumer brand than Warby Parker).

Sell the earning spike here and invest elsewhere.

Q4 Download

Let's now go through Warby Parker's latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q4 earnings summary is shown below:

Warby Parker's revenue grew 11% y/y to $212.0 million, actually missing Wall Street's expectations of $213.1 million (+12% y/y) by a one-point margin. Revenue growth decelerated two points versus 15% y/y growth in Q3.

This has made us worried about some of the recent customer trends that the company is experiencing. As shown below, Warby Parker’s count of active customers (defined as those who have made a purchase within the last twelve months) grew by only 30k in Q4, with y/y growth slowing to 7% (from 9.3% in Q3). We note as well that this is atypical seasonality for Warby Parker and for most DTC brands, as Q4 contains the core holiday period.

Management attributed a portion of the slowdown to macro factors and noted that prescription glasses units sold declined -6% y/y. Per CEO David Bilboa’s remarks on the Q4 earnings call:

In fiscal 2025, we delivered 13% revenue growth, driven by 47 new store openings, the most ever in a single year, high single-digit customer growth and mid-single-digit average revenue per customer growth. We believe this performance reflects continued market share gains. We drove healthy unit volumes, average selling price and customer growth, while prescription glasses units declined 6% industry-wide according to the Vision Council.

And while much of the category relied on significant price increases, we mitigated the impact of tariffs while preserving our unmatched value proposition and maintaining prices on the vast majority of our offerings, including our $95 prescription glasses.”

That said, we do note to Warby Parker’s credit that it is attempting to appeal to higher-value customers who are more likely to purchase more holistic vision care from the company - encompassing eye exams and contact lenses on top of eyeglasses. The rising mix of these customers has driven the company’s average revenue per customer 5.7% y/y higher to $324. The company also plans to try to work deals with insurance carriers to broaden insurance eligibility, which may help to pull in more customers.

Another major growth priority for 2026 is expansion of the company’s retail store network, which is the principal lever for Warby Parker to improve consumer brand recognition. The company ended FY25 with 323 retail stores, opening 47 new stores within the year. It plans to step up new store openings to 50 in FY26, marking 15% net location expansion for next year.

On the profitability front, Warby Parker’s gross margins declined -170bps y/y to 52.4%, owing to tariffs. That said, the company did manage to offset this headwind with a 340bps reduction in selling, general, and administrative costs as a percentage of revenue. As a result, adjusted EBITDA rose 10% y/y to $15.2 million, with margins holding roughly flat y/y at 7.2%.

Key Takeaways

While Warby Parker continues to post decent results amid what the company believes is a declining eyeglass industry, I find its >20x adjusted EBITDA multiple too rich in a market where bargains are plenty. Don’t count on AI smart glasses to provide a huge burst in revenue, either, as this is still an unproven concept at this stage that hasn’t gained broad consumer acceptance. Take advantage of the post-earnings upside to sell.

data.title: Northeast Community Bancorp: Attractive Valuation After A Strong Start To 2026
data.description:
Introduction

After a challenging 2025, shares in Northeast Community Bancorp (NECB) are off to a solid start in 2026, outperforming the broader iShares US Financials ETF (IYF). The gains come as NECB has made some progress on attracting new deposits in H2 2025, although more work remains on this front.

While Fed rate cuts and deposit pressure have resulted in a small contraction in NECB's net interest margin, I believe the shares offer further upside for the remainder of 2026, confirming my previous Buy rating on the company. My positive outlook is underpinned by:

  • A very undemanding 7.45x trailing P/E multiple representing a circa 40% discount to regional bank peers.
  • Solid capital position and a valuation below book value, making incremental share repurchases highly accretive.
  • Supreme credit quality, notwithstanding risks from a deteriorating macroeconomic backdrop, particularly in New York.

Readers not familiar with NECB may find the Company Overview section in my previous article insightful. The only change I would highlight is that following H2 2025 deposit inflows, the loan-to-deposit ratio has shrunk to 1.15x, still elevated relative to peers.

Q4 2025 Results Overview

NECB reported EPS of $0.79/share, a 5.3% Y/Y jump relative to the prior year quarter. The increase was principally driven by loan growth at 2.6% Y/Y, while credit quality remained supreme (0% nonperforming loans).

The company made notable progress on attracting new deposits, which were up 9.3% relative to H1 2025. Still, compared to the end of 2024, total deposits were still down by about 3.2%. Against the backdrop of a growing loan portfolio, NECB clearly needs to continue to put an emphasis on deposit inflows during 2026.

NECB navigated recent Fed rate cuts quite well, with the net interest margin standing at 5.18%, only 0.11% below the 5.29% achieved in Q4 2024. I would expect some incremental decline in net interest margins in 2026 as the Fed continues with Fed rate cuts, while NECB strives to further reduce its loan-to-deposit ratio.

Book value stood at $25.67/share at the end of 2025, a circa 10% Y/Y increase, which is quite impressive when you consider that NECB also paid a total of $0.80/share in four quarterly dividend payments. The bank recently authorized a third buyback program, although the start has apparently been quite slow, with shares outstanding up 1.1% Y/Y in Q4 2025.

To conclude, I believe NECB reported a solid set of financial results, notwithstanding the need to make further progress on deposit outflows.

Macro Backdrop

NECB operates exclusively in New York and Massachusetts. As such, any potential deterioration in credit quality may be precipitated by a worsening macroeconomic environment in these two states.

New York has seen a notable increase in the unemployment rate to 4.6% at the end of 2025, some 0.6% higher compared with July 2025. As such, I believe provisioning could pick up in 2026 should current trends persist.

As far as Massachusetts is concerned, the macroeconomic picture there is somewhat more stable, with the unemployment rate holding steady at 4.8% in recent months. Even so, both states exhibit an unemployment rate above the national average.

To sum up, with the caveat that unemployment data may improve alongside an expected pickup in U.S. economic growth in 2026, current macro indicators suggest some deterioration in credit quality for NECB this year.

Valuation and Rating

Even after the strong start to 2026, NECB shares still trade at a circa 6% book value discount, indicating persistent investor worries about H1 2025 deposit outflows. For comparison, regional bank peers held in the iShares U.S. Regional Banks ETF (IAT) at roughly 1.27x their book value.

The good news is that with NECB's robust CET1 capital ratio of 15.36%, the company can take advantage of the persistent book value discount via share repurchases.

Turning to profitability, NECB also scores well compared to regional bank peers. The bank generated $3.25/share in 2025 earnings, indicating a trailing P/E of 7.45x. Regional bank peers held in IAT trade at a much higher valuation of roughly 12.32x their trailing earnings. In essence, on a trailing P/E basis, NECB offers a discount of around 40% relative to its direct peers.

NECB only has one analyst estimate for 2026-2027 earnings, with 2026 EPS seen at $3.39/share, representing a growth rate of only 4.3% relative to 2025. I would view this estimate as conservative in light of NECB's low dividend payout ratio of only 0.25x, indicating that many of the above-mentioned headwinds stemming from deposit pressures and a deteriorating macro environment are likely priced in.

To conclude, notwithstanding risks that I will discuss in the next section, I anticipate NECB to continue to outperform regional bank peers, confirming my previous Buy rating on the shares.

Risks

As things stand, NECB boasts supreme credit quality and a healthy CET1 capital ratio. As such, risks in the immediate term look quite benign. That said, a potential further deterioration in New York/Massachusetts macroeconomic conditions may ultimately result in a rise in loan delinquencies.

72% of NECB's loan portfolio is concentrated in construction loans, with a further 18% allocation to residential real estate financing. While incremental Fed rate cuts create a favorable backdrop for the real estate sector in general, NECB's loan concentration will likely result in highly cyclical earnings, as opposed to regional bank peers, which typically exhibit greater diversification (although I should note that outsized real estate exposure is not that uncommon among the sector).

Last but not least, while NECB has made progress on attracting deposits in H2 2025, the company's wide discount relative to regional bank peers shows persistent worries about NECB's competitive position in the deposit market. In essence, failure to attract deposits at attractive terms may result in a further decline in NECB's net interest margin.

Conclusion

The broader U.S. financials sector has struggled to post gains so far in 2026, impacted by a decline in long-term risk-free interest rates, which will likely put pressure on net interest income. Jitters around private credit markets have also likely weighed on returns.

Against this backdrop, NECB shares have posted modest gains, with the bank reporting overall solid Q4 2025 results and making progress on attracting new deposits, although more work remains to be done on this front in 2026.

NECB stock trades at a wide discount to regional bank peers, indicating that risks related to a potential rise in non-performing loans and/or a further contraction in the net interest margin are already priced into the shares. As such, I see room for further NECB outperformance relative to U.S. financial peers, confirming my previous Buy rating on the shares.

Thank you for reading.

data.title: EHI: Double-Digit Yield Has Appeal, But Lack Of Coverage Means Caution
data.description:
Written by Nick Ackerman, co-produced by Stanford Chemist

Western Asset Global High Income Fund (EHI) is a closed-end fund that provides exposure to primarily high-yield investments, primarily corporate bonds, but also a significant sleeve of emerging market government debt. The credit quality is primarily BB and below, but there is a small slice of investment-grade exposure here as well. Given some relatively longer average life of the underlying portfolio and the small slice of investment-grade exposure, that does make the fund's effective duration a bit higher relative to its high-yield-focused peers.

The fund has seen its discount widen since our prior update, which makes it a bit more attractive to consider today. However, it is still trading near its longer-term average. In fact, there was a period of time when a double-digit discount wasn't all that uncommon, though that was a handful of years ago. The fund, maintaining its monthly distribution that is working out to over 13%, is likely keeping investors interested. While coverage of the distribution leads to sustainability questions, I suspect they won't be too quick to cut this payout to investors.

With that, I believe that EHI remains a hold today based on wanting to see a deeper discount level before considering it appealing enough to jump in. If that came with the impact of an overall market downturn, that would help to make it that much more interesting as well.

EHI Basics

  • 1-Year Z-score: -0.27
  • Discount/Premium: -4.63%
  • Distribution Yield: 13.15%
  • Expense Ratio: 1.49%
  • Leverage: 29.24%
  • Managed Assets: $288.57 million
  • Structure: Perpetual

EHI's investment objective is to seek "high current income, with a secondary objective of total return." To achieve that, the fund will "provide a global, leveraged portfolio of investment grade, below investment grade, and emerging market fixed-income securities."

Given that the fund is leveraged, that increases volatility and risk for investing in the fund. The other side of this is that it can also help to drive performance higher when things are going well. However, it also comes with a cost. When including those interest expenses, the fund's total expense ratio comes in at 4.14%

Performance - Distribution Likely Drives Increased Interest

Since our last update, the fund has provided positive total returns, though its price has declined somewhat since then. So the returns here were driven entirely by the distribution being paid out.

As the fund's discount also widened a touch during this period, that would have added further negative pressure to the actual share price relative to the fund's underlying NAV returns.

However, relative to the longer term, the fund still isn't looking like a bargain. Over the last five years, the fund's average discount has come in around 4.5%—about right where we are now. In looking back over the last decade, we can see the period where a 10%+ discount was quite normal.

During that widening discount period, it was when the fund had made a number of cuts in its payout. Since then, EHI has maintained its distribution for quite a number of years now, and the last move was to even increase it in early 2024. That tends to attract income-focused investors—particularly, those that also find higher yields enticing because the current distribution works out to 13.15%.

Based on the NAV rate, that works out to a hefty 12.54%. That's quite an elevated level and would call into question some sustainability issues over the longer term. Remember, a CEF can essentially pay whatever it would like as long as the NAV remains above $0.

With EHI, they were able to conduct a rights offering in 2024. It was dilutive to the NAV, as most ROs are, as they are done at a discount to the NAV per share at the time. Still, one of the reasons they were able to pull off an RO is because the fund was flirting around a premium.

They likely understand that any distribution cut would send the discount widening out quite materially. Therefore, despite the elevated level, I suspect they are quite content with keeping the payout right where it is in the hopes of eventually being able to pull the RO trigger once again. While it hits the NAV per share due to the dilution, the overall assets being managed increase nonetheless.

The last semi-annual report for the period ended November 30, 2025, showed that net investment income coverage came in at around 64%.

For most fixed-income CEFs, we'd ideally like to see this over 100%. However, this isn't all that common anymore these days as CEFs attempt to keep discounts narrow by paying out relatively higher distributions. That said, the current distribution coverage from EHI is quite low, even relative to some of its high-yield peers. Of course, this is what we would expect when we see a distribution rate that is pushing over 12% on a NAV basis.

EHI's Portfolio

Speaking of peers, over the longer term, the fund has underperformed most of its peers listed on CEFData. In the last year, their fortunes turned around, and they saw themselves amongst the top performers.

One of the reasons we could have seen this play out is that the fund primarily carries corporate bonds in various sectors, but it also carries a sleeve of emerging market government debt in a fairly meaningful allocation.

This can matter because high-yield emerging market bonds performed quite well in the last year relative to the high-yield corporate space. Overall, EHI is only holding around 59% of its portfolio in U.S. debt, with the remainder elsewhere around the globe. Below is a comparison between how U.S. corporate high-yield bonds performed relative to high-yield emerging markets, with the investible instruments iShares iBoxx $ High Yield Corporate Bond ETF (HYG) and the iShares JP Morgan EM High Yield Bond ETF (EMHY).

When it comes to the credit quality, the fund is primarily invested in BB and B allocations. Still, they allocate around 17% to BBB and above as well. With some of that higher-quality debt, which generally comes with a relatively longer maturity.

In the case of EHI, the weighted average life of the holdings comes in at 8.75 years, with an effective duration of 4.95 years. When comparing that to EMB, the effective duration comes in at 6.82 years, and HYG shows its portfolio with an effective duration of 2.75 years. Thus, we can presume that some of the longer duration is coming in from the emerging market government debt that EHI carries, making it relatively more interest rate sensitive with its longer maturity.

As a fund that leans heavily into below-investment-grade credit, they do have the common key feature to fight back against the risks that can pose—which is a significant number of holdings at 404 for the fund. This is then carried out through no individual position carrying too much of an overweight allocation. After the first handful of names, the allocations don't even reach 1% of the fund's weighting anymore.

Conclusion

When it comes to investing in EHI, the discount isn't quite there yet, even as it has widened a touch since our prior update. I'd personally feel more comfortable investing at an 8%+ discount level, and if that occurs during increased market volatility when high-yield spreads widen, that would be even more ideal. One of the key features of EHI is that it pays a relatively higher distribution rate while also providing a bit of exposure to emerging market debt. Unfortunately, that distribution coverage is rather weak, but I also don't suspect they have intentions of cutting it anytime soon. I think the main goal would be to get the fund to trade closer to a premium once again and then possibly initiate another rights offering.

data.title: The Fallout Of U.S.-Iran Round Two
data.description:
After months of the U.S. and Iran posturing—both politically and militarily—in the Persian Gulf, and following a previous attack on its nuclear program and air defenses in June, the U.S. and Israel have conducted another set of strikes. This time, the targets were much more numerous and varied.

It is unclear if more are to come, as the events are still unfolding.

This is what escalation looks like.

Iran escalated in tow, firing missiles at U.S. bases across the Middle East. Some were intercepted, with their intended targets either unknown or, more likely, undisclosed to the public at this time.

President Trump sent a message to the public following the attacks, which included addressing the Iranian people:

to the...people of Iran, I say tonight that the hour of your freedom is at hand...When we are finished, take over your government. It will be yours to take. This will be probably your only chance for generations.

For many years, you have asked for America's help...Now you have a president who is giving you what you want. So let's see how you respond. America is backing you with overwhelming strength and devastating force. Now is the time to seize control of your destiny, and to unleash the prosperous and glorious future that is close within your reach. This is the moment for action. Do not let it pass.

Reporting out of the Islamic Republic is sparse, since the government has shut down Internet access in the country (people are smuggling in Starlink nodes to counteract this), so it's unclear how the people are responding at this time. The unrest in the months leading up to this strike has been so widespread that it has been called a “2nd Iranian Revolution.” Time will tell how that will unfold.

For now, that's the necessary get-you-up-to-speed part. Now, let's talk about consequences.

Note: I’m mindful of the heavy human and political weight of current events, but for the purpose of this piece, I’m keeping the focus strictly on the potential market impacts.

The Speculators Are Still Driving Oil

I warned folks about oil in January, when this saga really started to get news coverage. Oil has been bought up on speculation that this event would cause the closure of key oil passageways. Increasingly YTD, the movement in the price of oil has been concentrated in speculation around geopolitical risk.

At the time, I was worried that there would not be another escalatory event, and oil would sell off as tensions cooled. Speculators have won, as oil surged higher following reports that Iran is indeed closing the Strait of Hormuz. This chokepoint is incredibly important because Kuwaiti, Bahraini, Qatari, Emirati, and Saudi oil all flow through there to large extents.

A closure of the strait would halt ~20% of the world's daily oil supply.

If this stoppage holds and is adhered to through the weekend, it could mean a spiral of speculators pouring into oil. This is stay-away territory, because the price of oil could go parabolic in response. It is still moderate right now, likely because the market is pricing in a return to normal with the strait within the next day.

It looks like investors are pricing in tanker delays and additional geopolitical risk, not a full closure of the straits just yet.

There is already evidence of ships turning around. Ship tracking sites are showing oil tankers making U-turns to avoid the strait. It is unclear if this ship, and others like it that are making similar maneuvers, are leaving due to the strait's closure or for their safety to avoid crossfire during a conflict. Many tankers may have insurance carriers that demanded they avoid the strait as news of strikes broke out, and so they turned around even if the Iranian authorities didn't cause it.

For now, this is still in the fog of war information-wise, and so it's unclear how much further oil could go. It will depend on the depth of escalation moving forward and what is really going on with passage through the strait.

The worse this conflict gets, the higher oil is likely to go, and I expect that to hold true until there is some resolution about the strait. That doesn't mean that there has to be resolution about Iran or their government. The U.S. breaking their control of the strait and allowing transit could cause oil to come back down quickly.

OPEC+ Still Has A Say

There is a point to note here that the price of oil was beaten down all last year, and so even though it has jumped on this recent speculation, its absolute levels are still fairly low to recent history.

One of the levers of the oil market is OPEC+, which Iran is part of but whose controlling members Iran just shot missiles at. Sure, the targets were American bases, but I cannot imagine that there is a single Gulf monarchy that is happy with Iran right now.

The next meeting is March 1st, and I imagine that they will work on making sure that OPEC+ oil is allowed through the strait. Whether that is achievable or not is unclear, so for now, all we can do is speculate.

Perhaps a solution is reached where Iran allows partial passage for OPEC+ tankers, but not for U.S. or EU-flagged vessels. Again, speculation.

Another thing that they will decide is their target output levels. They could hike production again to use volume to offset the price hikes. OPEC+ has been working on creating an oil glut over the last year, and while they slowed production recently, it is common for them to change direction quickly in response to events like these. This is especially poignant for the Gulf monarchies because they are responding to what is happening on their doorstep this time around, unlike with Venezuela.

Stocks Will Shake It Off

We don't buy any oil from Iran, and the U.S. doesn't import much from the affected countries. In fact, this closure really hurts China and India more than anyone else, although South Korea and Japan will also need to find a new supply if the straits really are closed.

The U.S. economy is unlikely to be affected by this major economic consequence of escalation with Iran. Stocks may sell off as fear sets in for traders and speculators. For the record, I do not believe we will go to war with Iran, but I do not control what narratives the market puts weight in.

It behooves us to remember that markets are forward-looking. They react to today's news, but it becomes priced in quickly, and tomorrow's news quickly takes over.

A friend said it best to me when we were discussing the potential of the U.S. attacking Iran again earlier this week:

They always do it on a Friday. That way, the markets can fall over the weekend. By Monday's open, there's been two news cycles. That's a lot of time for other stories to take over.

And history shows us the truth in this. Past wars have not been long-term negative catalysts for markets. They don't always even cause sell-offs.

Gold Wins the Day, Of Course

It was no surprise to see gold hit >$5,400 after the news dropped of escalation between the U.S. and Iran. Gold has been particularly responsive to geopolitical tensions since 2022, replacing the role of the U.S. dollar as the ultimate safe haven from chaos.

Imagine telling an investor in the 00s that traders would run to treasury duration to avoid geopolitical risk. They worry about what sovereigns are doing, so they buy sovereign debt? Mind-blowing.

Not the part about gold, though—that checks out for most people. Geopolitical risk invites investors to load up on an asset that sovereigns don't outright control.

Through last year, geopolitical risk was a strong driver for gold's returns. This is similar to oil, and so similar risks should be considered—a conclusion of the tensions could mean a sell-off is in store. Gold in particular is in a much more precarious position than oil since its producers are not putting it in a glut.

We can see just how much of a drag momentum has been, and I expect it to continue to be, as long-term holders realize their gains after the best year for gold in decades.

If you want to know more about my gold convictions, take a look at my most recent gold-focused article, “Gold Isn't Near a Peak.” It's crazy to think that the article was written just a month ago, and gold is up ~15% since.

Conclusion

Ultimately, the jury is still out on how things will unfold in Iran. The U.S. has not given any signals if more attacks are imminent, and it's unclear if or for how long Iran intends to try to close the Strait of Hormuz. That will be a determining factor for how markets react.

Oil is bid up on speculation, and a full closure, which would likely include direct U.S. intervention in the area, could cause oil to spike. Beware if you are trading oil or oil-related ETFs.

I don't expect too much pain to bleed over into the U.S. economy even if oil is stopped, as we do not import much from the Persian Gulf. The stock market may react negatively at first, but time will heal things, as other news cycles will begin to factor in. This conflict does not stop the next earnings call from happening, and so, for now, I am not worried about much movement in indexes, although individual firms with exposure to the conflict area are another story.

Gold is the key winner of rising geopolitical tensions in our current market, and I expect precious metals across the board to benefit regardless of the outcome in Iran.

Crises and conflicts like this are a good reminder that position sizing is more important than security selection. It is very difficult to time these events and to trade them, so ensuring that your risk exposure is appropriate is critical for your portfolio when bombs start flying—and they are flying.

I hope for peace.

Thanks for reading.
